module.p: Verbs are words which typically describe situations – events, states, activities &c.
Is e faclan a bheir cunntas gu cumanta air suidheachaidhean a tha ann an gnìomhairean – tachartasan, staidean, dèanadasan &c.
For example – ith eat, fàg leave, ...

Verbs are divided into three groups, depending on how they are formed –
Derived verbs are formed from adjectives or nouns, usually by addition of a suffix eg. gealaich whiten, cuimhnich remember.
Compound verbs are formed from other verbs, usually by addition of a prefix eg. ath-sgrìobh rewrite, craobh-sgaoil broadcast.
Simple verbs are not formed from other words eg. cuir put, fosgail open.
Verbs have mood – every verb form is either indicative or imperative.
Tha modh aig gnìomhairean – tha gach gnìomhair taisbeanach no àithneach.

Indicative verbs are conjugated for tense, status and voice -
Every indicative verb form is either past, future, conditional or present.
Every indicative verb form is either independent, dependent, or relative.
Every indicative verb form is either active or passive.
The past stem of a verb is formed by leniting the verbal root, eg. cuir → chuir. If the resulting form starts with a vowel, then it is prefixed with dh’, e.g. ith → dh’ith, fosgail → dh’fhosgail.
The past independent active and past relative active forms of a verb are identical to the past stem, eg. cuir → (a) chuir.

The past independent passive and past relative passive forms of a verb are created by adding the suffix -(e)adh to the past stem, eg. cuir → chuireadh, ith → dh’itheadh. Roots ending in -ail, -air, -in(n) are subject to syncope eg. fosgail → dh’fhosgladh.

The past dependent forms of a verb are created by prefixing the particle do to the corresponding past independent form, eg. cuir → cha/an/nach do chuir (active), cha/an/nach do chuireadh (passive); ith → cha/an/nach do dh’ith (active), cha/an/nach do dh’itheadh (passive).

p.note: In older writings, dependent forms in do dh’ are often simply d’ eg. d’òl(adh) instead of do dh’òl(adh); d’fhosgail, d’fhosgladh instead of do dh’fhosgail, do dh’fhosgladh.

module.p: The future independent active form of a verb is created by adding the suffix -(a)idh to the verbal root, eg. cuir → cuiridh. Roots ending in -ail, -air, -in(n) are subject to syncope eg. fosgail → fosglaidh.

The future relative active form is created by adding the suffix -(e)as to the (lenited) verbal root, eg. cuir → a chuireas. Again, roots ending in -ail, -air, -in(n) are subject to syncope eg. fosgail → a dh’fhosglas.
The future dependent active form of a verb is identical to the verbal root, eg. cuir → cha chuir, an/nach cuir.

The future passive forms are created by adding the suffix -(e)ar to the verbal root, eg. cuir → cuirear (independent), a chuirear (relative), cha chuirear, an/nach cuirear (dependent). Again, roots ending in -ail, -air, -in(n) are subject to syncope eg. fosgail → fosglar.

The conditional dependent active forms of a verb are created by adding one of the conditional suffixes to the verbal root –
-(a)inn (first-person singular) eg. cuir → cha chuirinn, an/nach cuirinn.
-(e)amaid (first-person plural) eg. cuir → cha chuireamaid, an/nach cuireamaid.
-(e)adh (other) eg. cuir → cha chuireadh, an/nach cuireadh. Note that roots ending in -ail, -air, -in(n) are subject to syncope eg. fosgail → fosglainn, fosglamaid, fosgladh.

The conditional dependent passive form of a verb is created by adding the suffix -te to the verbal root eg. cuir → cha chuirte, an/nach cuirte. The same suffix is used even if the verb ends in a broad consonant eg. òl → chan/an/nach òlte.

The conditional independent and relative forms of a verbs are created by leniting the corresponding conditional dependent form eg. cuir → (a) chuirinn (first-person singular), (a) chuireamaid (first-person plural), (a) chuireadh (other active), (a) chuirte (passive). If the resulting form starts with a vowel, then it is prefixed with dh’, e.g. ith → (a) dh’ithinn, (a) dh’itheamaid, (a) dh’itheadh, (a) dh’ithte; fosgail → (a) dh’fhosglainn, (a) dh’fhosglamaid, (a) dh’fhosgladh, (a) dh’fhosgailte.

p.note: In older writings, conditional passive forms in -teadh are often found eg. c(h)uirteadh, (dh’)òlteadh. With verbal roots ending in a broad consonant, the spelling was sometimes altered to preserve the slender-to-slender spelling rule eg. òl → chan/an/nach òilte(adh). Alternatively, the broad suffix -tadh was sometimes used eg. òl → chan/an/nach òltadh.

module.p:
Imperative verbs are conjugated for voice, person and number –
Every imperative verb is either active or passive.
Every active imperative verb is either first-person, second-person or third-person.
Every first- or second- person active imperative verb is either singular or plural.

The active imperative forms are conjugated as follows –
The first-person singular active imperative form is created by adding the suffix -(e)am to the verbal root eg. cuir → cuiream.
The first-person plural active imperative form is created by adding the suffix -(e)amaid to the verbal root eg. cuir → cuireamaid.
The second-person singular active imperative form is identical to the verbal root eg. cuir → cuir.
The second-person plural active imperative form is created by adding the suffix -(a)ibh to the verbal root eg. cuir → cuiribh.
The third-person active imperative form is created by adding the suffix -(e)adh to the verbal root eg. cuir → cuireadh. Roots ending in -ail, -air, -in(n) are shortened with each of these suffixes eg. fosgail → fosglam, fosglamaid, fosglaibh, fosgladh.
The passive imperative form is created by adding the suffix -tear to the verbal root eg. cuir → cuirtear, fosgail → fosgailtear.

module.p: Also – bi be.

Most verb forms have exactly one core nominal dependent, or subject eg.
tha iad sgìth they are tired – the personal pronoun iad they is the subject of the verb tha are
chunnaic am balach beag feòrag anns a’ chraoibh the little boy saw a squirrel in the tree – the common noun balach boy is the subject of the verb chunnaic saw

The subject of a verb can be either –
a common or proper noun
a personal or demonstrative pronoun.

The following verb forms never have an explicit subject, because they are assumed to have an implicit, built-in subject –
first-person conditional (active) verb forms like èighinn I would put, (cha) èigheamaid we would (not) put
passive verb forms like èighear someone will put, (cha) èighte someone would (not) put
first- and second-person imperative verb forms like èigheam let me put!, èighibh you put!
In addition, an active verb form may lack an explicit subject when it occurs as the answer to a yes/no question.

Verb forms can also have a secondary nominal dependent, or object eg.
chì mi a-màireach sibh I will see you tomorrow – the personal pronoun sibh you is the object of the verb chì will see
sgrìobh Màiri litir thugam Mary wrote me a letter – the common noun litir letter is the object of the verb sgrìobh wrote

Verbs can also have a secondary nominal dependent, or object, which again can be either –
a common or proper noun (phrase) in the nominative case
a personal or demonstrative pronoun.

In addition to subjects and objects, verbs can also have one or more non-nominal complements eg.
thug Ealasaid ubhal dhan bhodach Elizabeth gave the old man an apple – the preposition dhan to the introduces a complement of the verb thug gave
thuirt a’ chailleach gun robh i sgìth the old woman said that she was tired – the particle gun that introduces a complement of the verb thuirt said
feumaidh tu an leabhar seo a leughadh you must read this book – the infinitival leughadh reading is a complement of the verb feumaidh must

In addition to subjects and objects, verbs can also have one or more non-nominal complements, which can be either –
a preposition (phrase)
a clause introduced by one of the verbal particles gun, an or nach
an infinitival (phrase).

Finally, verbs may have one or more adverbial modifiers eg.
chaidh iad dhan bhaile an-dè they went to the town yesterday – the adverb an-dè yesterday is a (temporal) modifier of the verb chaidh went
an do choinnich thu do bhean anns an oilthigh? did you meet your wife at the university? – the preposition anns in introduces a (locative) modifier of the verb choinnich did meet
nam bithinn mì-thoilichte, dh’fhàgainn if I were unhappy, I would leave – the particle nam if introduces a (conditional) modifier of the verb dh’fhàgainn I would leave

The main uses of independent verbs are –
To introduce a positive declarative sentence eg. Thèid sinn dhan bhùth. We will go into the shop.
To introduce a (positive declarative) conjunct of one of the coordinating conjunctions agus and and no or eg. dh’èirich mi agus dh’ith mi bracaist I got up and I ate breakfast
To introduce the complement of the subordinating conjunction oir because eg. tha i toilichte oir cheannaich i càr ùr she is happy because she has bought a new car

The main uses of relative verbs are –
To introduce the complement of the relative particles a who, which and na that which eg. an leabhar a sgrìobhas mi the book which I will write, na chuirear thugam what will be sent to me
To introduce the complement of the conditional particle ma if eg. ma bhios mi sgìth, fuirichidh mi aig an taigh if I am tired I will stay at home

The main uses of dependent verbs are –
To introduce the complement of the negative, interrogative and subordinating particles cha, an, nach and gun eg. cha robh e beàrtach he was not rich, thuirt i gun do sgrìobhadh leabhar she said that a book had been written
To introduce the complement of the conditional particle nan if eg. nan deigheadh tu do Ghlaschu dh’fhaodainn do fhaicinn if you went to Glasgow I could see you
Like any word or phrase, every verb form is associated with one or more potential senses.

When a verb form is associated with a bounded sense, it is being used as a perfective verb. Perfective verb senses are viewed from the outside, as unitary, whole events, generally in the past, eg.
bhrùchd/chlisg Màiri Mary burped/started
bhàsaich Seumas James died
shnàmh Raonaid Rachel swam

Perfective verb senses are not compatible with bounding adverbials like fad na h-oidhche all night long or gu briseadh an latha until daybreak.
Chaidh Màiri dhan leabaidh. Bhrùchd i fad na h-oidhche. Dh’èirich i aig briseadh an latha.
Chaidh Màiri dhan leabaidh. Bha i a’ brùchdadh fad na h-oidhche. Dh’èirich i aig briseadh an latha.
Chaidh Màiri dhan leabaidh. Bhrùchdadh i fad na h-oidhche. Dh’èirich i aig briseadh an latha.
Chaidh Raonaid don ionad-spòrs. Shnàmh i fad leth uair a thìde. Ghabh i fras, agus chaidh i dhachaigh.

Perfective verb senses can be used in narrative foreground.
Thig Seumas a-steach. Chlisg Màiri. Shuidh i sìos.
Chaidh Raonaid don ionad-spòrs. Shnàmh i, ghabh i fras, agus chaidh i dhachaigh.
When a verb form is associated with a non-bounded sense, it is being used as an imperfective verb.
